SENT.plain: A 75-year-old male with a long history of gastroesophageal reflux symptoms developed adenocarcinoma proximally within a long segment of Barrett's esophagus
He was taken for esophagectomy and gastric pull-up, but intraoperatively, he was found to have a marginal blood supply in the gastric tube
A temporary left-sided esophagostomy was created with the gastric tube sutured to the left sternocleidomastoid muscle in the neck
Pathology showed an intramucosal adenocarcinoma, limited to the muscularis mucosa with surrounding high-grade dysplasia and intestinal metaplasia
The proximal esophageal margin showed no tumor cells, but there was low-grade dysplasia within Barrett's esophagus
He was reconstructed after several months, and 2 years after reconstruction, the patient noticed a nodule at the former esophagostomy site
Biopsy revealed an implant metastasis of esophageal adenocarcinoma
Here, we review the literature and discuss the possible etiology
